desc.size: Shrub or small tree, to 8 m tall, trunk diameter to 30 cm. Crown open, rounded.

part.partText: light brown to gray, tinged with red, thin, shallowly fissured, scaly.
stout, upright, brown to dark reddish purple, at first downy, becoming smooth.
dark reddish purple, 7 - 9 mm long, egg-shaped, flattened, long-pointed, shiny.

alternate, with 1 - 2.5 cm long leafstalks; bright green above, silvery or white-waxy and bluish green beneath, 5 - 12 cm long, 1.5 - 3.5 cm wide, lanceolate to narrowly elliptic, base rounded to tapering, tip pointed, margins irregularly wavy-toothed, thick, firm, hairy when young.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy, cylindrical catkins; female catkins loosely flowered, greenish, 1.5 - 3 cm long, scales dark brown, ovary hairy; male catkins fuzzy, soft, white or silvery, 2 - 4 cm long, stamens 2, scales dark brown, anthers yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in 6 - 8 cm long clusters; light brown, 8 - 12 mm long, flask-shaped, finely hairy; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix discolor is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having leaf margins that are not distinctly toothed or down-curved (revolute). Salix bebbiana is similar but has gray-hairy leaves. Salix x conifera, the hybrid between S. discolor and S. humilis, has relatively smaller catkins and fruit than S. discolor, with twigs that remain hairy into maturity and leaves that sometimes have rusty hairs underneath.

speciesPage.flowering: Early April to early May, before the leaves.
speciesPage.habitatEcology: In the Chicago Region, Salix discolor is common in the marshy and swampy ground of shrub-dominated communities, bottomland woods, and moist prairies. Occurs along lakes, streams, roads, and railroads. May also be found in ditches, fens, bogs, and sandy areas.

notes.comments: Planted as an ornamental. Florists use leafless branches of immature male catkins in floral arrangements.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Discolor means “of two different and usually distinct colors,” which refers to the leaves.
